0.body: Goal: Create a file and initialise pygame.
0.title: Task 1: Set Up

1.body: In VS Code, click on File and then New File... File New File You should see something like this pop up after you cilck 'New File' Pop Up Enter the name of your file (e.g. 'my_game.py') my_game.py ``` NOTE: It’s super important to include .py at the end of the file name so VS Code knows it's Python code! Press 'ENTER' and something looks like this should pop up my_game.py Press 'Desktop' and then 'Create File' to save your file to the Desktop my_game.py my_game.py AND NOW YOU HAVE CREATED YOUR PYTHON FILE!!! YOU CAN START CODING my_game.py
1.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Make a Python File » Task 1.1: Make Python File
1.title: Task 1.1: Make Python File

10.body: No crashing! Your window should stay open until you click the X! You should see something like this: black game window
10.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Loop » Checkpoints
10.title: Checkpoints

11.body: First save the image path as a variable : e.g.background_image = "images/background/wooden_floor.jpeg" Then load it using pygame.image.load(background_image) make sure the background fits the window Use pygame.transform.scale(...) draw the background onto the screen use screen.blit(...)
11.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Add Background Image » Task 2.3: Add Background Image
11.title: Task 2.3: Add Background Image

12.body: A background_image variable (path to the image) A background variable (the scaled loaded image) A screen.blit(variable, coordinate) line inside your while running: loop A background showing up instead of a black screen!
12.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Add Background Image » Checkpoints
12.title: Checkpoints

13.body: Change the text that appears at the very top of your game window use a Pygame function pygame.display.set_caption(). load an image using pygame.image.load(...) use Pygame function pygame.display.set_icon() to set the image. The path to your icon should be something like this: "images/game_icon.png"
13.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Add Icon and Game Title » Task 2.4: Add a Game Title and App Icon
13.title: Task 2.4: Add a Game Title and App Icon

14.body: Have your customised game title Have your customised icon
14.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Add Icon and Game Title » Checkpoints
14.title: Checkpoints

15.body: Goal: Make a player that can move and be seen on the screen.
15.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Task 3: Making a player
15.title: Task 3: Making a player

16.body: Your task is to create a player class with the following properties name image sprite position_x position_y
16.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Create a Player Class » Task 3.1 Create a player class
16.title: Task 3.1 Create a player class

17.body: Your task is to create an instance of the player class. Hint: something = ClassName() Doing so will call the __init__(self, ...) method of the class. Now, thinking back to yesterday, how might we access the variables of this class?
17.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Create a Player Instances » Task 3.2: Create an instance of player
17.title: Task 3.2: Create an instance of player

18.body: Under the player method, we need to create a draw method(). How might we create a method inside a class? If you are stuck have a read here . Perhaps the screen.blit(...) function could be useful... Now, in order for the player position to be updated very often, where would we call this draw method?
18.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Draw Method » Task 3.3: Create the draw method
18.title: Task 3.3: Create the draw method

19.body: Your task is to create the move method.
19.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Task 3.4: Create the move method
19.title: Task 3.4: Create the move method

2.body: Now that you have created your Python file, it's time to start setting it up for Pygame! At the very top of your Python file, you need to import the Pygame library. Initialising Pygame You should now see something like this: Pygame Init
2.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Import Pygame » Task 1.2: Import Pygame
2.title: Task 1.2: Import Pygame

20.body:
First, you need to find whether a certain key is being pressed or not. Similar to yesterday, we can use a function called pygame.key.get_pressed() . Hint: This returns a list of booleans.
For example, the return value may look something like this -> [False, False, False, False, True, False, False] How might we check whether the 7th key is pressed?
20.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Task 2.4.1
20.title: Task 2.4.1

21.body:
Secondly, we need to update the position_x and position_y variables of our player according to what key was pressed. For example, something like if w is pressed move up
else if a is pressed move left
else if s is pressed move down
else move right
21.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Task 2.4.2
21.title: Task 2.4.2

22.body: Add player.move() and player.draw() to the game loop.
22.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Implement Player Move method » Task 2.4.3
22.title: Task 2.4.3

23.body: We’re going to fix the trailing images issue by re-drawing the background to the screen every time the game loops. Draw the background to the screen again inside the game loop before drawing the bird. That fixed it!
23.breadcrumbs: MAKING A PLAYER » Fix duplicating Poco » Task 3.5: Fix duplicating Poco
23.title: Task 3.5: Fix duplicating Poco

24.body: Goal: Add multiple entities that are related to each other. In this example we have added food, but you are free to add what you wish, as long as it is appropriate.
24.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Task 4: Adding other entities
24.title: Task 4: Adding other entities

25.body: Start by creating a new class called Food.
25.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Class » Task 4.1: Create a Food Class
25.title: Task 4.1: Create a Food Class

26.body: class Food: Inside your Food class, create a special function called __init__.
26.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Class » Example:
26.title: Example:

27.body: Use the def keyword to define the method. The __init__ method should accept 4 inputs : name image position_x position_y Save each of these inputs into the object using self. Inside your __init__() method, set a default size for your food. Still inside the __init__() method, load the image file using Pygame's image load function. Scale the loaded image to the correct size using Pygame's transform scale function. Save the final scaled image into the object (e.g., self.sprite).
27.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Class » Hints:
27.title: Hints:

28.body: A Food class (or a class of things you want to have) An __init__() method that: Saves the name, image, and position Sets a default size Loads and scales the sprite A ready-to-use object for your game!
28.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Class » Checkpoints
28.title: Checkpoints

29.body: Create a dictionary called foods, this dictionary will hold all the food items you want to appear in your game.
29.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Dictionary » Task 4.2: Create a Food Dictionary
29.title: Task 4.2: Create a Food Dictionary

3.body: Goal: Create a visible game screen with a background, title, icon and a game loop.
3.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 2: Creating a game screen
3.title: Task 2: Creating a game screen

30.body: Use curly braces {} to create a dictionary. Save it in your main code before your game loop starts. Inside your dictionary, add entries for each food you want Each key should be the name of the food (like "banana", "grapes", etc.). Each value should be a list that contains: The path to the image file The x position The y position
30.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Dictionary » Hint:
30.title: Hint:

31.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create a Food Dictionary » Hint for structure:
31.title: Hint for structure:

32.body: Create a new empty list called active_foods, this list will store all the Food objects you create. Write a for loop that goes through every item in your foods dictionary. In each loop, you will create a new Food object.
32.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Initialise Active Foods List » Task 4.3: Initialise Active Foods List
32.title: Task 4.3: Initialise Active Foods List

33.body: Use .items() to loop through both the key and value . The key will be the name of the food. The value will be a list containing: [image path, x position, y position] Create a New Food Object for Each Item
33.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Initialise Active Foods List » Hint:
33.title: Hint:

34.body: key -> name value[0] -> image path value[1] -> x position value[2] -> y position
34.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Initialise Active Foods List » Hint:
34.title: Hint:

35.body: An empty active_foods list created A loop that: Goes through every food in your dictionary Creates a Food object Adds it into the active_foods list
35.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Initialise Active Foods List » Checkpoints
35.title: Checkpoints

36.body: Create a new method called draw.
36.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create Food Draw Method » Task 4.4: Create Food Draw Method
36.title: Task 4.4: Create Food Draw Method

37.body: Use the def keyword. It should be written inside your Food class (at the same indentation level as __init__()). This method won’t take any arguments (only self). This method will draw the food onto the screen. Draw the Sprite Onto the Screen
37.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create Food Draw Method » Hint:
37.title: Hint:

38.body: Use screen.blit(...) to draw. The first thing you want to draw is the sprite (image). The position to draw at is (position_x, position_y).
38.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create Food Draw Method » Hint
38.title: Hint

39.body: A draw() method inside your Food class which knows how to: Draw the sprite And place it at the correct position
39.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Create Food Draw Method » Checkpoints
39.title: Checkpoints

4.body: Before we make our game we need to set up the screen to display it! Make a screen that is 800 pixels wide and 600 pixels tall For example: To make a screen that is 100 pixels wide and 200 pixels tall you could use this code WIDTH = 100 HEIGHT = 200 Create a window** of that size using the Pygame function pygame.display.set_mode()
4.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Screen » Task 2.1: Create Game Screen
4.title: Task 2.1: Create Game Screen

40.body: Now that each Food knows how to draw itself, it's time to actually draw all the food onto your game window during the game! You will loop through all active foods inside your while running: game loop.
40.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Task 4.5: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop
40.title: Task 4.5: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop

41.body: Create a for loop inside your while running: loop which loop over the active_foods list. In each loop call the draw() method on the food to draw it on screen.
41.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Step 1: Loop Over active_foods
41.title: Step 1: Loop Over active_foods

42.body: Inside the for loop: use player's method to check for interaction with the food. call the food’s .draw() method.
42.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Step 2: Drawing and Interaction
42.title: Step 2: Drawing and Interaction

43.body: A for loop inside the main game loop You can interact with the food Draw the food onto the screen All your food are visible
43.breadcrumbs: MAKING OTHER ENTITIES » Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Checklist
43.title: Checklist

44.body: Goal: Detect whether the player is colliding with any of the food.
44.title: Task 5: Collision

45.body: Create an extra property in the player and food class. Use the .get_rect().move() function to create a rectangle that moves with the class' sprite. Create a method called update(self) in the player class. Copy the property you just wrote into this method. Call the player update method in the main game loop, just underneath player.draw()
45.breadcrumbs: COLLISION » Creating Hitboxes » Task 5.1: Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
45.title: Task 5.1: Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods

46.body:
# sprite.get_rect() creates a rectangle the size of the image
# .move() moves whatever it's attached to to an x and y coordinate
self.hitbox = self.sprite.get_rect().move(self.position_x, self.position_y)
46.title: Relevant code

47.body: Create a property called interact_foods(self, food) in the food class Use the colliderect to check whether the rectangular hitboxes are colliding If they are colliding, remove food from the active_foods list
47.breadcrumbs: COLLISION » Detecting Collision » Task 5.2: Check whether two hitboxes are colliding
47.title: Task 5.2: Check whether two hitboxes are colliding

48.body:
# Collision is True is the hitboxes are colliding and False if not
collision = self.hitbox.colliderect(food.hitbox)
48.title: Relevant code

49.body: Goal: Add a score, a win condition. Finishing this task finishes the basic features of your game.
49.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Task 6: Finishing the game.
49.title: Task 6: Finishing the game.

5.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Screen » YOU CANNOT SEE YOUR SCREEN YET
5.title: YOU CANNOT SEE YOUR SCREEN YET

50.body: Create a player score variable that counts how many items that a player has picked up. Everytime that a user picks up a new item, update this variable.
50.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Implement a Score » Task 6.1: Create a player score
50.title: Task 6.1: Create a player score

51.body: We need to have a way that the player can win the game. If the the player picks up all the items, (or the score is equal to the number of items), then end the game and quit. Perhaps setting running = False will do something... if all items are collected: end the game
51.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Implement a Win Condition » Task 6.2: Game Win condition
51.title: Task 6.2: Game Win condition

52.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Display the Score » Task 6.3: Show the score on the screen
52.title: Task 6.3: Show the score on the screen

53.body: We need to render the score on the screen. Perhaps, we could do something like font.render() might help us...
53.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Display the Score » Step 1.
53.title: Step 1.

54.body: We now need to blit the text onto the screen. You can think of it as the previous step drew us the image, and now we need to 'put' it on the screen. Where might we put this function? Use: screen.blit(Surface, Coordinate)
54.breadcrumbs: FINISHING THE BASE GAME » Display the Score » Step 2.
54.title: Step 2.

6.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Screen » You must complete Task 1.2 first BEFORE YOU CAN SEE A SCREEN WHEN YOU RUN YOUR PYGAME!
6.title: You must complete Task 1.2 first BEFORE YOU CAN SEE A SCREEN WHEN YOU RUN YOUR PYGAME!

7.body: Two variables for width and height A screen object created using Pygame and your variables
7.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Screen » Checkpoint
7.title: Checkpoint

8.body: Use a variable called running and set it to True at the start Then you need a while loop which keep looping while the game is running . Inside your while running: loop, you need to check what the player is doing .
8.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Loop » Task 2.2: Create Game Loop
8.title: Task 2.2: Create Game Loop

9.body: Use for event in pygame.event.get(): Go through all the events (like mouse clicks, window close, etc.) If the player close the game (event.type == pygame.QUIT`), you need to stop the loop ! At the end of your while loop, refresh the screen with pygame.display.update()
9.breadcrumbs: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Create a Game Loop » Hint:
9.title: Hint:
